I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In November 2007, an Asian Development Bank (ADB) mission attended a meeting on 
national  health  accounts  (NHAs)  for  Pacific  island  countries  hosted  by  the  World  Health 
Organization (WHO) in Sydney, Australia.1 The meeting, attended by representatives from 
10 Pacific island countries,2 was of great interest to ADB in the context of its Pacific Strategy3 to 
support improved policy formulation processes. Discussions among country participants at the 
meeting elicited a demand for a regional technical assistance (RETA) program to support 
Pacific  countries  in  the  development  and  use  of  NHAs  for  guiding  better-informed  health 
financing  decisions.  The  meeting  also  agreed  on  a  framework  for  the  development  and 
institutionalization  of  NHAs  in  the  Pacific,  for  which  the  countries  desired  support  for 
implementation. 
 
2.  In follow-up to the above, the RETA Fact-Finding Mission4 was fielded in June 2008, 
during which ADB participated in the WHO meeting on user-fees impact and lessons for the 
Pacific in Nadi, Fiji Islands. The meeting venue was used to conduct side consultations with key 
country participants on the technical assistance (TA) scope and design. The Mission also 
reached an understanding with WHO, the proposed executing agency, on the objective, scope, 
costs, financing, implementation arrangements, and consultants’ outline terms of reference. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Lack of Evidence and Information Guiding Policy Decisions. Health care financing is 
a complex domain and a key public finance policy issue for the Pacific. While the Pacific as a 
region spends a relatively large share of public money on health services, there is a serious lack 
of information and analysis guiding the choice and impact of health financing policies. Often, 
health sector budget levels are forecasted and decisions are made without due consideration 
given to their efficiency in technical or allocation terms. As Pacific countries increasingly face 
cost pressures and challenges to the long-term sustainability of their health financing systems, 
the need for evidence to support effective decision-making and review of policies is becoming 
even more imperative. Poor management of resources is among the factors driving the cost of 
health care. As such, the importance of NHAs5 has been increasingly recognized. The data—or 
“evidence”—provided in NHAs allows countries to (i) see the whole picture on sector-level 
health resource flows, and (ii) evaluate measures for efficient allocation of resources across the 
health system. 
 
4.  New  Challenges  and  Stresses  to  Health  System. Health financing in the Pacific 
appears  in  the  context  of  “high  spending  and  low  efficiency”  trends  (as  opposed  to  “low 
spending and low efficiency” trends elsewhere in Asia). With a shift in disease patterns to 
chronic  diseases,  limited  public  resources,  and  volatile  external  aid,  Pacific  countries 
increasingly face a common challenge in sustaining their health systems against rising costs of 
health care. The bulk of health resources are directed at curative care, which is less cost-
effective. Governments also now have a new regulatory role to play, given increased private

sector participation in health services provision. Thus, there is a need for better management of 
health sector resources, and for evidence provided through tools such as NHAs, to guide more 
efficient use of public money and explore effective health financing options.  
 
5.  Lack  of  Data  Misses  Important  Poverty  Issues.  There  is  an  astounding  lack  of 
monitoring  and  analysis  related  to  health  financing  policies  in  the  Pacific.  High  public 
expenditures on health (supported by external resources) and largely free health care provision 
mean that financial access and equity have tended to be good in much of the Pacific (although 
physical access has been a problem for outer island populations). In recent years, however, a 
number of governments in the region have begun to explore user fee options as a means to 
additional resource mobilization. According to WHO, out-of-pocket health spending has notably 
increased in countries such as Fiji Islands, Samoa, and Tonga. Thus, there is a concern that the 
current health financing structures in Pacific countries is increasingly moving towards highly 
inequitable methods of financing, which impedes access to health care and can deepen poverty. 
There  are  also  large  populations  of  contract  workers  in  many  Pacific  countries  without 
affordable access to health care. Data constraints and the lack of effective expenditure tracking 
mechanisms such as NHAs mean that such poverty-related policy issues often go unnoticed.  
 
6.  Uniqueness of Pacific Countries and Need for Contextually-Relevant Solutions. A 
key lesson in the midterm review of the Pacific Strategy is that the design of any proposed 
intervention must be based on and driven by the Pacific context. Pacific island countries are 
different from larger East Asia countries—their institutional set-ups and accounting principles 
are often different, and knowledge sharing by the larger countries on NHAs is not readily 
adaptable to the Pacific setting. There is a need for Pacific countries to benefit from experience 
within the Pacific region, and to learn from countries with more similar needs and experiences. 
This requires effective regional networking and promoting cross-country analysis to develop 
relevant strategies, approaches, and framework customized to the unique Pacific setting. While 
health financing issues vary with country, similar skills are required to study and analyze them. 
Given the size and scattered nature of Pacific geography, a regional approach affords the 
potential for seeking economies of scale in this regard. 
 
7.  Current  Network  Mechanisms  are  Limited  for  Pacific  Countries.  Some  Pacific 
countries (Samoa and Tonga) are part of larger regional NHA networks (Asia Pacific NHA 
Network [APNHAN]). However, their experiences often do not “feed up” into attempts at joint 
regional products and common frameworks. Knowledge-sharing experiences of larger East 
Asian  countries  are  not  quite  “feeding  down”  to  smaller  Pacific  countries  either.  A  more 
consolidated Pacific “voice” and experience can more effectively contribute to joint regional 
products, and for concertedly adapting lessons from larger APNHAN member countries to apply 
to the Pacific setting. There is a need for Pacific countries to better link up with and tap the 
experience of existing health policy research networks, while fostering subregional learning and 
knowledge sharing within the Pacific context. Such Pacific subregional networking would also 
strengthen the knowledge base and initiatives of wider regional networks. 
 
8.  Need to Enhance Ownership. Ownership is critical and proposed solutions are unlikely 
to succeed if not owned and initiated by Pacific island communities. Often, external TA for 
Pacific  countries  tends  to  be  strictly  output-oriented,  with  little  attention  to  encouraging 
ownership and capacity building. Although a number of Pacific countries received initial TA from 
WHO to develop NHA first rounds, these efforts need to be furthered to ensure ownership and 
strengthen initial capacity building.  
 
9.  Need for an NHA Framework Suited to Pacific Setting. WHO and partner agencies 
have developed NHA guidelines for low-income countries. However, many Pacific countries do

3
not  readily  belong  to  the  “low-income  countries”  classification.  Thus,  there  is  a  need  for 
development of an NHA framework suited to the Pacific setting. The above-mentioned draft 
framework for the development and institutionalization of NHAs in the Pacific,6 developed with 
inputs from Pacific government representatives, needs further support for its refinement and 
development of an implementation plan.   
 
10.  Need for Partnerships Based on Comparative Advantage. ADB’s long-term strategic 
framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020)7 sets forth, as key principles, partnerships with 
international organizations, a regional approach, and an improved knowledge base among 
developing member countries (DMCs) for better decision making. In line with this, the TA is 
based on institutional comparative advantages of ADB and WHO and serves a shared objective 
to promote effective, equitable, and sustainable health sector resource allocations. ADB’s 
relationship with ministries of finance and planning/statistical agencies also places it well to 
complement WHO technical strengths and better link health policy making with public financing  
decisions. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The desired impact of the TA is that public, private, and development partner resource 
allocations for health services are more effective among the participating Pacific countries. The 
expected outcome of the TA is that decision makers routinely use NHAs for policy making on 
health sector resource allocations. The key outputs are as follows: (i) availability of total health 
resources  and  expenditure  data  among  the  participating  Pacific  countries,  (ii)  a  functional 
Pacific subnetwork on NHAs that is also well linked with larger NHA regional networks, and (iii) 
development of an evidence-based approach to promote policy use of NHA data in the Pacific 
context. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.    
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will support the planning, development, and institutionalization of NHAs in the 
Pacific  and  promote  subregional  cooperation  in  the  process.  It  incorporates  principles  of 
ownership, knowledge sharing, and capacity strengthening in its design. The scope of the TA 
seeks to benefit all Pacific DMCs as a knowledge product and in lessons sharing (about 8–10 
Pacific countries are expected to participate in subregional NHA networks and forums). Under 
component 2 (conducting NHA pilot tests), Fiji Islands, Federated States of Micronesia (FSM), 
and Vanuatu were initially selected as priority countries.8 Expected outputs and lessons from 
this TA will primarily be disseminated at country level and subregional forums, targeting NHA 
practitioners and health financing policy makers. Health networks, Pacific Open Learning Health 
Net, research and academic institutions, and other related mechanisms will also be used for 
knowledge sharing on TA outputs. The four components of broad activities supported under the 
TA are as follows.

13.  Component 1: Developing of NHA Regional Resources and Standardized Materials. 
This component will develop NHA regional resources and standardized materials, tables, and 
templates adapted to the Pacific context, which countries could easily draw on and adapt for 
their NHA development and data use. This will include (i) refining and updating the framework 
for development and institutionalization of NHAs in the Pacific, and major activities in the related 
action plan; (ii) developing simple and standardized materials for developing NHAs suited to the 
Pacific setting (including guidelines, tables, data instruments, and work plan templates); and 
(iii) ad hoc advisory support as requested by national governments for NHA development, 
institutional capacity building, and internal arrangements. Outputs under this component will be 
produced in a consultative manner through a subregional forum. 
 
14.  Component 2: Conducting NHA Pilot Tests. This component will support planning, 
development, and institutionalization of NHAs in at least three pilot countries (FSM, Fiji Islands, 
and Vanuatu) where the NHA development process was initiated and rough estimates were 
produced with WHO technical support. The project will build on this initial groundwork and be 
implemented  in  a  manner  that  promotes  ownership  and  skills  transfer.  This  will  include 
(i) country-level workshops at inception to create in-country awareness and demand for NHAs 
(i.e., building on initial experience of the first rounds); (ii) planning and development of NHAs 
(using standardized materials developed under component 1), including hands-on training in 
data collection, organization, and analysis; (iii) country-level workshops to disseminate NHA 
information for policy use; and (iv) a subregional workshop to promote cross-country analysis of 
NHA data findings. The component will also ensure links with other survey vehicles in the 
country (such as demographic health surveys) for efficient data collection. 
 
15.  Component  3:  Establishing  a  Pacific  NHA  Subnetwork.  This  component  will 
establish  a  Pacific  NHA  subnetwork  to  promote  subregional  networking  on  NHAs.  This  is 
envisaged  to  be  a  knowledge-sharing  network  of  individuals  and  agencies  involved  in 
advocating, implementing, or supporting NHA activities in the Pacific. Networking will cover 
support and information sharing in all areas of advocacy, practical implementation, and policy 
use related to NHAs in the Pacific. This subnetwork is expected to be closely linked with 
APNHAN, especially for support in technical areas. The scope, form, and effective mechanism 
of networking and collaboration suited to Pacific needs and circumstances will be determined. 
Network activities will include support for APNHAN members to participate as resource persons 
in relevant Pacific forums, as well as for active Pacific participation at larger regional workshops 
and conferences. Development of a Pacific-specific module on NHAs, which would likely be 
disseminated through the Pacific Open Learning Health Net and/or Fiji School of Medicine, will 
also be supported under this component. 
 
16.  Component 4: Research and Capacity Building on NHA Data for Policy Use and 
Advocacy. This component will commission a study on how policy makers have used NHAs, 
and the various factors that determine the extent to which NHAs have or will affect the policy 
process in the Pacific. The study will, for example, explore if improved availability of health 
expenditure data has contributed to evidence-based policy making in Samoa and Tonga, the 
two Pacific countries that routinely produce NHAs. It will also gather lessons from the initial 
experiences of Fiji Islands, FSM, and Vanuatu (which have completed first rounds) and other 
Asian countries. The report will recommend advocacy strategies to promote and build capacity 
in NHAs for policy use in the Pacific (e.g., policy briefing kits on “key facts”, incorporation of 
NHAs into Pacific Islands Forum regional strategy, etc.). Findings from this study will be shared 
through a regional workshop on using NHAs for policy advocacy and creating political demand 
for them. Collaboration with the World Bank (which is supporting NHAs as part of health sector 
reform in Samoa and Tonga) will be sought under this component.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at the equivalent of $1.1 million. ADB will provide 
$1.0 million, financed on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government 
of Japan. The TA funds will be disbursed based on ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2008, as amended from time to time). WHO will provide the balance of $0.1 million 
equivalent  in  kind,  including  project  management  and  coordination,  technical  advice  and 
resources, office space and administrative support to consultants, and organization of workshop 
and capacity building activities. Further cofinancing from other development partners may be 
sought  at  a  later  stage  to  support  additional  NHA  pilot  countries  and  TA  complementary 
activities. Details of the cost estimates are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The WHO Regional Office for the Western Pacific (WHO-WPRO) will be the Executing 
Agency for the TA. All TA activities and workshops will be implemented though the WPRO 
Health Systems Development Division under the guidance and direction of the director. The TA 
will fund a TA project coordinator (national, 11 person-months) who will be based in the WPRO 
office.  Under  the  general  supervision  of  the  WPRO  Health  Systems  Development  division 
director, the TA project coordinator will have responsibility for day-to-day coordination and 
management of TA activities and for ensuring timely delivery of outputs. The budget provides for 
purchase of computer equipment for the TA team. The equipment will be procured by the TA-
funded project coordinator, with prior approval from ADB’s Pacific Department, in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
19.  ADB  financing  will  support  a  total  of  25  person-months  of  international  consulting 
services and 15 person-months of national consulting for the TA. All consultants will be recruited 
by ADB, in close consultation with WHO-WPRO, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The TA project coordinator (national, 
11 person-months)  will  be  based  in  Manila  and  recruited  as  an  individual.  The  remaining 
consulting services requirements (25 person-months international and 4 person-months national) 
will  be  sourced  through  a  firm  using  the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  (with 
simplified technical proposal) in the following categories: (i) six health economists (16 person-
months  international  and  2  person-months  national);  (ii)  health  policy  research  specialist 
(2 person-months international and 2 person-months national); (iii) health network specialist (4 
person-months  international);  and  (iv)  3  person-months  of  unallocated  international 
consultancies for ad hoc advisory services are included in the package. WHO-WPRO will 
provide “team leadership” to the consultants and will be responsible for their coordination and 
supervision  as  well  as  in  facilitating  liaison  with  national  agencies.  The  outline  terms  of 
reference of consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months starting in January 2009. An agreement 
between WHO and ADB will follow the approval of the TA. Letters of no-objection will be 
obtained from the selected pilot countries under the RETA prior to commencing activities in 
each  country.  If  additional  cofinancing  is  sought  at  a  later  stage  of  the  project,  suitable 
arrangements will be worked out accordingly with the relevant agencies.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Strengthening Evidence-Based Policy-Making in the Pacific: Support for Development of 
National Health Accounts, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  assist  Pacific  island  countries  in  developing, 
producing,  and  institutionalizing  national  health  accounts  (NHAs).  It  will  support  the  NHA 
capacity building process, policy-relevant use of NHA information, and develop NHA regional 
resources including a Pacific NHA subnetwork.  
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) financing will support a total of 25 person-months 
in international consulting services and 15 person-months in national consulting services under 
the TA. All consultants will be recruited by ADB, in close consultation with the World Health 
Organization  Western  Pacific  Regional  Office  (WHO-WPRO),  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The TA project 
coordinator (11 person-months, national), based in Manila, will be recruited as an individual. 
The remaining consultancy requirements (25 person-months international and 4 person-months 
national) will be sourced through a firm using the quality- and cost-based selection method (with 
simplified technical proposal). The Health Systems Development Division at WHO-WPRO, the 
Executing Agency, will be responsible for guiding TA activities, supervising consultants, and 
facilitating liaison with national agencies.

under this component will be produced in a consultative manner with inputs from country

2.  Component 2: Conducting NHA Pilot Tests 
 
a.  Health  Economists  –  NHA  pilot  tests  (3  person-months  each, 
intermittent) 
 
6.  The consultants will support planning, development, and institutionalization of NHAs in 
select pilot countries (Fiji Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, and Vanuatu) where the NHA 
development process was initiated and rough estimates were produced with WHO’s technical 
support. It will build on this initial groundwork and be implemented in a manner that promotes 
ownership and skills transfer. The scope of work will broadly include the following: 
 
(i)  review ongoing NHA initiatives and estimates in pilot countries and develop NHA 
work plan suited to each country;  
(ii)  organize country-level workshops at inception to create in-country awareness 
and demand for NHAs; 
(iii)  verify  health  financing  and  expenditure  classifications  in  terms  of  sources, 
financial agents, providers, and functions; 
(iv)  review and improve NHA matrices and data collection strategies; 
(v)  train the NHA team on methodology and tools to prepare NHAs; 
(vi)  organize and assist data collection and analysis; 
(vii)  prepare NHA report and policy briefs for discussions; 
(viii)  organize  NHA  consultation,  workshops,  and  dissemination  of  NHA  reports, 
including assisting in a subregional workshop to promote cross-country analysis 
of NHA data findings; and 
(ix)  develop  NHA  institutionalization  plan  and  provide  necessary  guidelines  for 
implementation. 
 
7.  Qualifications: At least a Master’s degree in public health, economics, or related field 
with minimum 7 years’ experience working in areas related to health financing research and 
advisory work. Ability to work effectively with national counterparts in capacity building/skills 
transfer and in a consultative manner is necessary. Knowledge of the Pacific region strongly 
preferred.  
 
3.  Component 3: Establishing a Pacific NHA Subnetwork 
 
a.  Health Networking Specialist (4 person-months, intermittent) 
8.  This consultant will lead the establishment of a Pacific NHA subnetwork to promote 
subregional networking on NHAs. The scope of work will broadly include the following: 
 
(i)  review the regional NHA network and identify gaps and opportunities for better 
Pacific integration;  
(ii)  develop a framework for establishing Pacific NHA subnetwork, including scope, 
form,  and  effective  mechanism  of  networking  suited  to  Pacific  needs  and 
circumstances;  
(iii)  prepare operational plans and activities for the subnetwork; 
(iv)  provide estimates of funds and identify potential funding agencies; 
(v)  identify the key issues to be resolved for successful operation and sustainability 
of NHA subnetwork; and 
(vi)  conduct a subregional workshop to launch the subnetwork initiative and provide 
follow-up mentoring/advisory support as required to ensure sustainability.

Appendix 3  11 
9.  Qualifications. At least a Master’s degree in public health, economics, or related field 
with minimum 7 years’ experience working in areas related to health networking and related 
advisory work. Knowledge of the Pacific region strongly preferred.  
 
b.  Health Economist – NHA Pacific Module (3 person-months, intermittent) 
 
10.  In close collaboration with a national consultant, the consultant will support development 
of a Pacific-specific module on NHAs, which would likely be disseminated through the Pacific 
Open Learning Health Net and/or Fiji School of Medicine.  
 
11.  Qualifications. At least a Master’s degree in public health, economics, or related field 
with minimum 7 years’ experience working in areas related to health financing and related 
advisory work. Knowledge of the Pacific region strongly preferred.  
 
4.  Component 4: Research and Capacity Building on NHA Data for Policy Use 
and Advocacy 
 
a.  Health Policy Research Specialist (2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
12.  In close collaboration with a national consultant, the consultant will support routine use 
of NHAs for policy-making on health sector resource allocations. The scope of work includes the 
following: 
 
(i)  Conduct a study on how policy makers have used NHAs and the various factors 
that determine the extent to which NHAs have or will affect the policy process in the 
Pacific. The study will cover the following: 
(a)  explore if improved availability of health expenditure data has contributed 
to evidence-based policy-making in Pacific and other Asian countries; 
(b)  recommend advocacy strategies to sensitize NHAs and their integration 
in health sector policy development and policy use in the Pacific;  
(c)  identify research areas to promote NHA demand and use; 
(d)  identify the key issues to be resolved for NHA capacity building for policy 
and advocacy work;  
(e)  propose a related capacity building plan for use of NHAs in health sector 
policy development, in collaboration with regional NHA institutions and 
network; and 
(f)  organize a regional forum to share information on findings of the study. 
 
13.  Qualifications. At least a Master’s degree in public health, economics, or related field 
with minimum 7 years’ experience working in areas related to health financing and policy 
research.

12  Appendix 3 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  Project Coordination 
 
a.  TA Project Coordinator (11 person-months)  
 
14.  Under  the  overall  supervision  of  the  director  of  the  Health  Systems  Development 
Division, and direct supervision of the regional advisor on Health Care Financing, the consultant 
will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day  coordination  and  management  of  TA  activities  and  for 
ensuring timely delivery of outputs. The scope of work will broadly include the following: 
 
(i)  assist WHO in management, coordination, and supervision of consultants; 
(ii)  help ensure effective coordination and timely delivery of consultants’ TA outputs, 
(iii)  facilitate consultants in liaison with national agencies;  
(iv)  assist in organization of workshops and capacity building activities; and 
(v)  other tasks relevant to management and coordination of the Project as requested 
by WHO/ADB.   
 
15.  Qualifications. At least a Master’s degree in management, health economics, or related 
field with minimum 4 years’ experience related to management and administration of projects in 
international  development.  S/he  must  have  good  communications  and  interpersonal  skills. 
Knowledge  of  the  Pacific  region  and  experience  working  with  international  organizations 
preferred.  
 
2.  Component 3: Establishing a Pacific NHA Subnetwork 
 
a.  Health Economist – NHA Pacific Module (2 person-months) 
 
16.  The consultant (based in the Fiji Islands) will support the international consultant in 
development of a Pacific-specific module on NHAs. S/he will support liaison and networking with 
other  national  institutions  in  the  Pacific  for  effective  dissemination  and  promotion  of  NHA 
curriculum materials (e.g., through the Pacific Open Learning Health Net and/or Fiji School of 
Medicine).  
 
17.  Qualifications. At least a Master’s degree in public health, economics, or related field 
with minimum 5 years’ experience working in areas related to health financing and related 
advisory work. Knowledge of the Pacific region strongly preferred.  
 
3.  Component 4: Research and Capacity Building on NHA Data for Policy Use 
and Advocacy 
 
a.  Health Policy Research Specialist (2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
18.  The consultant will provide research support to the international consultant on a study on 
routine use of NHAs for policy-making on health sector resource allocations. The study will 
cover how policy makers have used NHAs and the various factors that determine the extent to 
which NHAs have or will affect the policy process in the Pacific. S/he will also assist in the 
organization of a regional forum to share information on findings of the study. 
 
19.  Qualifications. At least a Master’s degree in public health, economics, or related field 
with 3–5 years’ experience working in areas related to health financing and policy research.
